title: 103_s2012
content: The Act may be cited as the "Protection From Coercive Employment Agreements Act" and is related to the Civil Rights Act of 1964. The Civil Rights Act of 1964 is amended to prohibit employers from discriminating against individuals who refuse to submit claims to mandatory arbitration or make arbitration a condition of employment. The Civil Rights Act of 1964 is amended to include any unlawful employment practice described in section 704(c) (U.S.C. 2000e-16(a)). The Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967 is a federal law that prohibits age discrimination in employment. The Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967 is amended to prohibit employers from requiring mandatory arbitration for age discrimination claims. The Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967 is amended to prohibit mandatory arbitration for age discrimination claims, including any unlawful practice described in section 4(g). The Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 is outlined in Section 4. Section 102 of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 (42 U.S.C. 12112) is amended to include a prohibition on mandatory arbitration for discrimination against qualified individuals with disabilities in job-related procedures. The curr_chunk discusses prohibiting mandatory arbitration related to employment terms and conditions for individuals who refuse to submit claims under the Americans with Disabilities Act. SEC. 5 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 is amended to include provisions prohibiting discrimination under the Americans with Disabilities Act in employment by departments, agencies, and instrumentalities. SEC. 6 addresses revised statutes. Section 1977 of the Revised Statutes (42 U.S.C. 1981) is amended to prohibit discrimination in employment contracts related to mandatory arbitration. No individual or entity can refuse to hire, discharge, or discriminate against a person for not submitting claims to arbitration, or make arbitration a condition of employment.
